The bicameral structure of the Pennsylvania General Assembly consists of 203 members in the House of Representatives and 50 members in the Senate. The Speaker of the House of Representatives plays a crucial role in holding sessions and casting tie-breaking votes, while the President of the Senate fulfills similar responsibilities in the Senate. Session laws are published in the official "Laws of Pennsylvania" and codified in the "Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes," providing a framework for the state's legal system. The legislature has the authority to expel members with a two-thirds vote, and expelled members are restricted from running for reelection. Additionally, members are appointed by the majority and minority leaders of the State Legislature for specific roles, contributing to the organization and functioning of the legislative body. The election of various state offices, including the Treasurer, Auditor General, and Attorney General, further illustrates the democratic process within the state government.
